dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been seeing this really interesting, um, kind of baffling trend lately, right? Despite all the talk about how good employee education programs are for companies, a bunch of major corporations are actually quietly scaling them back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been seeing this really interesting, um, kind of baffling trend lately, right? Despite all the talk about how good employee education programs are for companies, a bunch of major corporations are actually quietly scaling them back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild, isn't it? I mean, you hear about Taco Bell and Lowe's, like, just stopping their partnerships with Guild Education, this big Denver-based company. It's just... you don't expect that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild, isn't it? I mean, you hear about Taco Bell and Lowe's, like, just stopping their partnerships with Guild Education, this big Denver-based company. It's just... you don't expect that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And Guild's co-founder and CEO, Rachel Carlson, she had this, uh, really tense press conference last week. She was saying things like, "investing in our frontline workforce creates a more toxic environment."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And Guild's co-founder and C E O, Rachel Carlson, she had this, uh, really tense press conference last week. She was saying things like, investing in our frontline workforce creates a more toxic environment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Toxic environment? Wow. That's a strong statement. And wasn't she flanked by, like, some really random people? Like, the MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle and others?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Toxic environment? Wow. That's a strong statement. And wasn't she flanked by, like, some really random people? Like, the M S N B C anchor Stephanie Ruhle and others?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson was joined on-stage by Rothy's President Kerry Whorton Cooper, The Cru Founder & CEO Tiffany Dufu, MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle and Vanguard's Head of U.S. Wealth Planning Research Maria Bruno.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Totally unexpected. But the real kicker, I think, is *why* this is happening. Carlson herself admits that every CEO they've ever worked with has mentioned that sending employees back to school has consistently failed to lift profits, recruitment, *and* retainment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Totally unexpected. But the real kicker, I think, is why this is happening. Carlson herself admits that every C E O they've ever worked with has mentioned that sending employees back to school has consistently failed to lift profits, recruitment, and retainment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, [overlapping] so it's not just about the economic uncertainty then? It's that these programs, like, weren't actually delivering the ROI they promised?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so it's not just about the economic uncertainty then? It's that these programs, like, weren't actually delivering the R O I they promised?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! I mean, Guild estimates that 64 million white-collar workers are going to need more education to compete in an automated world, but then you have Walmart, the nation's largest employer, reducing their Live Better U program.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! I mean, Guild estimates that sixty four million white-collar workers are going to need more education to compete in an automated world, but then you have Walmart, the nation's largest employer, reducing their Live Better U program.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And now Walmart's program only covers tuition if the employee contributes a thousand dollars *a day*, right? That's just... that's insane. Who can afford that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now Walmart's program only covers tuition if the employee contributes a thousand dollars a day, right? That's just... that's insane. Who can afford that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A thousand a day! It's like, what's the point? And Stephanie Ruhle actually mentioned in an interview that analysts, you know, they really only care about the "good" a company is doing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A thousand a day! It's like, what's the point? And Stephanie Ruhle actually mentioned in an interview that analysts, you know, they really only care about the good a company is doing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, clearly, is not translating to actual financial benefits if, uh, Carlson's admission is true. It's all about optics versus, like, the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, clearly, is not translating to actual financial benefits if, uh, Carlson's admission is true. It's all about optics versus, like, the bottom line.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Guild itself, despite serving millions of employees, has attracted over $7 million in debt. So, they're actually pivoting away from educational *options* now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Guild itself, despite serving millions of employees, has attracted over seven million dollars in debt. So, they're actually pivoting away from educational options now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank. Guild is now looking at how to expand education options to workers in the gig economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Seven million? Yikes. But, I did hear something about, like, a tax incentive being their biggest win? Like with Lyft and tuition reimbursement?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seven million? Yikes. But, I did hear something about, like, a tax incentive being their biggest win? Like with Lyft and tuition reimbursement?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers. Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty ironic. Lobbying to preserve that tax incentive, allowing companies to offer nontaxable education assistance, might be Guild's greatest success yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty ironic. Lobbying to preserve that tax incentive, allowing companies to offer nontaxable education assistance, might be Guild's greatest success yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.
